resources.string: Turn your phone into a working tricorder.

Tricorder
\ 
\ Tricorder displays real data from the sensors built into your device.
\ 
\ This screen displays brief help on Tricorder. For the full manual, press "manual" below.
\ 
\ CONTROLS
\ 
\ Select between the available data views (see VIEWS below) using the buttons on the left.
\ 
\ In the GRAV and MAG views:
\ • touch the X/Y axis plot to switch between absolute and relative modes. When you enter relative mode, the current values are stored; the plot starts displaying changes relative to those values.
\ • touch the numeric data display to toggle it to an X/Y/Z graph plot; red is X, green is Y, and blue is Z.
\ 
\ In the GEO view, touch the satellite display to change its mode.
\ 
\ In the EMS view, touch the "WiFi Pwr" button at the top-right to turn the WiFi on and off.
\ 
\ In the SOL view, touch the "Mode Alt" button at the top-right to display different information; tap the Sun image to see different Sun views.
\ 
\ VIEWS
\ 
\ GRAV shows the local gravitational field, showing the individual components on an X/Y plot and a vertical gauge for the Z axis. Additionally an altitude gauge shows the angle above or below the tricorder's horizontal plane. Below this the absolute magnitude of the gravitational field is graphed, and then the raw numeric data is displayed, in units of m/s²: "X", "Y" and "Z" are the acceleration values in each of the three dimensions; "Az" is the direction of the gravitational field in the X-Y plane; "Alt" is the elevation of the gravitation pull above or below the horizontal, in degrees; and "Mag" is the absolute magnitude of the gravitational field, in units of m/s². When this becomes zero, you are in free fall.
\ 
\ MAG shows the local magnetic field, in the same format. The X-Y plot can be used like a compass; keep the altitude at zero to see exactly which way the magnetic field is pointing. The values displayed are in micro-Tesla.
\ 
\ ENV shows some environmental sensor readouts, if your device has the appropriate sensors fitted: light level, object proximity, and temperature. Each graph's header shows the current value in numeric form. Light readings are in lux; proximity is measured in metres; temperature is in degrees celsius.
\ 
\ Note that the values of these sensors can only be displayed if your device actually has the sensors equipped (the G1 phone, sadly, does not, but other devices do). If the sensors are missing, simulated data can be displayed; see the preferences for this option. A blue indicator in the header for each sensor indicates when it is in simulation mode.
\ 
\ GEO shows geographic information from the various providers which your device has. "Cellular" displays location from the cellular phone network; "GPS" is the GPS location, if GPS is enabled. Below these an indication of the satellites in view is displayed; tap it to toggle between a sky diagram and signal strength bars. The sky diagram also indicates true north (not magnetic north, although the accuracy still depends on your device's magnetometer, which may not be great).
\ 
\ Locations are shown in latitude and longitude degrees and minutes, with fractional minutes. "Alt" is the altitude in metres, and "Acc" is the estimated accuracy of the fix in metres. If the location provider provides course data, then "Head" is the direction you are moving in, and "Spd" is your speed in metres per second.
\ 
\ The latest available fix data, if there is any, will always be displayed. Note that this data may be old. The data is coloured to indicate its age, and the age is also shown in the header bar for each location provider.
\ 
\ EMS scans the electromagnetic spectrum for radio signals (as supported by hardware). Detected signals are shown as strength bars and a numeric strength indicator -- zero is no signal (or too weak to be useful); 31 is maximum for cellular, and 41 seems to be maximum for WiFi. At the top-right corner you will see a "WiFi Pwr" button which turns the WiFi on and off.
\ 
\ For cellular, we display the cell ID, the network provider, and the signal strength above the strength bar. For WiFi networks, we display the frequency in GHz, access mode, network ID, and signal strength. The access mode is blank for an open access point; '!' for an ad-hoc network (beware!); '*' for WEP encryption; '#' for WPA encryption; '?' for unknown. The WiFi data is refreshed periodically; the age of the displayed WiFi data is shown in the WiFi header bar.
\ 
\ In the preferences you can enable WiFi ping. With this on, the device will ping after each WiFi network scan; an echo ping indicates the strength of the strongest detected signal. (No echo means no detected WiFi.)
\ 
\ SOL displays information on the state of the Sun and solar wind. This information is downloaded from the internet, and it's downloaded as a very low-priority task so as not to affect your device's performance. Hence, it may take some time for the information to actually appear. At the top-right corner you will see a "Mode Alt" button to toggle between two different display modes.
\ 
\ The 'Protons' graph displays low- (blue), medium- (yellow), and high- (red) energy protons; the 'Electrons' graph displays low- (blue) and high- (red) energy electrons. The 'Spots,Flares' graph displays the numbers of sunspots (red), optical flares (blue), and X-ray flares (purple). The Sun image shows images of the Sun in different wavelengths of light; tap it to step through the available images.
\ 
\ MENU
\ 
\ The "menu" button gets you to the program settings, the help screen (this one), and the about box. In settings, you can set the basic sound level to off, quiet, or loud (note that you can also control the sound volume using the hardware volume keys). You can enable WiFi ping; see "EMS" above. You can set your preferences for how the display rotates, or not. And you can enable simulation of data for missing sensors; see "ENV" above.
\ 
\ GENERAL
\ 
\ Note that the availability and accuracy of the information presented depends on the underlying hardware. In particular the magnetic field data is known to be unreliable on some currently available devices, and the gravity reading can be affected by playing music.
\ 
\ You'll see a link to the project home page at the bottom of this screen; check it out for more info on Tricorder. Tricorder is an open project, so if you want to join in and make contributions, you can. See the project page for information.
\
